‚ö†Ô∏è Proton announces Proton Pass, a password manager - https://techcrunch.com/2023/04/20/proton-announces-proton-pass-a-password-manager/
‚ö†Ô∏è Proton Pass is now in beta | Proton - https://proton.me/blog/proton-pass-beta

Proton Pass is now in beta | Proton

Proton Mail announce the launch of the beta version of Proton Pass, a password manager that uses end-to-end encryption to protect login credentials. This is the first password manager built by an encryption and privacy company and is open source and publicly auditable upon launch. It is one of the first password managers to include a fully integrated two-factor authenticator and supports autofill. While the beta is currently available on iPhone/iPad, Android, and desktop, it does not have a Firefox browser extension at this time.

- Proton announces the launch of Proton Pass beta
- Password manager uses end-to-end encryption on all fields and is auditable upon launch
- Proton Pass is the first password manager built by a privacy company
- It is one of the first password managers to include a fully integrated two-factor authenticator and supports autofill
- Beta is available on iPhone/iPad, Android, and desktop, but not Firefox, with browser extensions for Brave and Chrome available
- Proton Pass set to redefine the role of password managers in online security
- Feedback can be given to pass@proton.me or on Twitter or Reddit

‚ö†Ô∏è iOS 17 will reportedly set the stage for sideloading apps on iPhone - https://techcrunch.com/2023/04/17/ios-17-will-reportedly-set-the-stage-for-sideloading-apps-on-iphone/

Quickstart - Testcontainers for Go

Testcontainers for Go provides a tool for spinning up and managing dependencies via Docker for integration or end to end tests. This tutorial covers the basics of spinning up Redis Testcontainers using Go.

- Testcontainers for Go is ideal for integration or end to end tests with Docker.
- Use system requirements page before installation.
- Install Testcontainers for Go using `go get github.com/testcontainers/testcontainers-go`.
- With Redis container initialization, specify the Docker image to use, list the ports to be exposed, and wait for a log message indicating the container is ready to accept requests.
- The container can be created to start automatically or manually.
- Clean up with `defer` statements and container termination functions.
- Get the container's endpoint and configure with the Redis client for testing.
- Run the test using `go test`.
- More advanced Redis examples can be found on the Testcontainers for Go example page.

‚ö†Ô∏è SQL Maxis: Why We Ditched RabbitMQ And Replaced It With A Postgres Queue - https://www.prequel.co/blog/sql-maxis-why-we-ditched-rabbitmq-and-replaced-it-with-a-postgres-queue
‚ö†Ô∏è Announcing FerretDB 1.0 GA - a truly Open Source MongoDB alternative | FerretDB Blog - https://blog.ferretdb.io/ferretdb-1-0-ga-opensource-mongodb-alternative/
‚ö†Ô∏è Announcing FerretDB 1.0 GA - a truly Open Source MongoDB alternative | FerretDB Blog - https://blog.ferretdb.io/ferretdb-1-0-ga-opensource-mongodb-alternative/

Announcing FerretDB 1.0 GA - a truly Open Source MongoDB alternative | FerretDB Blog

FerretDB is now production-ready as a truly Open Source MongoDB alternative built on PostgreSQL, released under the Apache 2.0 license. FerretDB enables users to run MongoDB workloads on other database backends while retaining the opportunities provided by MongoDB's current ecosystem.

- FerretDB is now production-ready as a truly Open Source MongoDB alternative built on PostgreSQL.
- Docker images for production and development and RPM and DEB packages are available for download.
- FerretDB supports createIndexes and dropIndexes commands, $unwind, $limit, and $skip stages, and $sum accumulator within the $group stage for more refined calculations and manipulations of collection data.
- Partial support for server commands such as collStats, dbStats, and dataSize is enabled to gather more information about collections, databases, and server performance.
- FerretDB has over 40 contributors, more than 130 merged pull requests, over 5,300 stars and 200 forks on GitHub, over 100 running instances with telemetry enabled, and over 10,000 downloads.
- FerretDB aims to create a new standard for document databases with MongoDB compatibility and set a new standard to enable different database engines to run document database workloads using a standardized interface.
- FerretDB offers a fully pluggable architecture and supports other backends, including PostgreSQL, Tigris, SAP HANA, and SQLite (in development).
- Feedback, contributions, and partnerships are welcome, and the FerretDB community is available on Slack and GitHub, ready to discuss ideas.

Cryptographic details matter, and Proton Pass uses a strong bcrypt password hashing implementation (weak PBKDF2 implementations have made other password managers vulnerable) and a hardened implementation of Secure Remote Password (SRP) for authentication. Proton Pass is also one of the first password managers to include a fully integrated two-factor authenticator (2FA) and supports 2FA autofill. This is meant to make it easier to use 2FA everywhere since it‚Äôs one of the most effective safeguards for your online accounts.

Proton Pass is now in beta | Proton

Proton Mail announce the launch of the beta version of Proton Pass, a password manager that uses end-to-end encryption to protect login credentials. This is the first password manager built by an encryption and privacy company and is open source and publicly auditable upon launch. It is one of the first password managers to include a fully integrated two-factor authenticator and supports autofill. While the beta is currently available on iPhone/iPad, Android, and desktop, it does not have a Firefox browser extension at this time.

- Proton announces the launch of Proton Pass beta
- Password manager uses end-to-end encryption on all fields and is auditable upon launch
- Proton Pass is the first password manager built by a privacy company
- It is one of the first password managers to include a fully integrated two-factor authenticator and supports autofill
- Beta is available on iPhone/iPad, Android, and desktop, but not Firefox, with browser extensions for Brave and Chrome available
- Proton Pass set to redefine the role of password managers in online security
- Feedback can be given to pass@proton.me or on Twitter or Reddit

Bard now helps you code

Bard, an AI language model is now helping people with coding. While it's an experimental tool, Bard can provide various new ways to write code, help debug, and optimize the code. But, users are advised to double-check Bard's responses and review code for errors, bugs, and vulnerabilities.

- Bard may provide inaccurate or incomplete code snippets
- Users must carefully review and test code before relying on Bard for it
- Bard can help users write, debug, and optimize code
- Users can request Bard to make the code faster or find error handling clauses
- Bard cites the source if the output is heavily based on an existing open-source project
- Bard is being used for everyday tasks like crafting presentations, writing lesson plans, inventing recipes, and planning workouts
- Bard's new feature for coding has great potential to accelerate software development and inspire innovation in solving complex engineering challenges.

Pricing v3, plans, packages, and debugging ¬∑ Tailscale

Tailscale has announced its third generation of plans and pricing. The free plan now includes three users, while monthly paid plans will only charge users for additional users who actively exchange data over Tailscale. Annual prepaid plans will have a new structure, and monthly prices per user remain the same. The changes are designed to reduce friction, which the company hopes will increase its R0 value. There are also more free nodes, and Tailscale has removed several limits, anticipating improved flexibility and growth. Finally, the company will use usage-based billing for monthly self-serve customers.
- The third generation of Tailscale plans and pricing has been launched, with the free plan expanding from one to three users.
- Monthly paid plans will only charge users for additional users who actively exchange data over Tailscale.
- Annual prepaid plans will have a new structure, and monthly prices per user remain the same.
- The company hopes these changes will reduce friction, which it believes will increase its R0 value.
- Tailscale has removed several limits, anticipating improved flexibility and growth.
- There are more free nodes, and usage-based billing will be offered for monthly self-serve customers.
- Tailscale will use metered billing to help customers avoid unexpected bills.

ARMO ‚Äì –Ω–∞—á–∞–ª–æ –¥–≤–∏–≥–∞—Ç—å—Å—è –≤ —Å—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–Ω—É –æ–ø—Ä–µ–¥–µ–ª–µ–Ω–∏—è —Ä–µ–ª–µ–≤–∞–Ω—Ç–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ —Ç–∞–∫–∏—Ö –Ω–æ—Ç–∏—Ñ–∏–∫–∞—Ü–∏–π –∏ —Å–æ—Ä—Ç–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∫–∏ —Ç–µ—Ö —á—Ç–æ –º–æ–≥—É—Ç —Ä–µ–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ –Ω–µ—Å—Ç–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—É ‚Äì –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–∞—è —Å—Ç–∞—Ç—å—è –∏ –Ω–∞–ø—Ä–∞–≤–ª–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Ä–∞–∑–≤–∏—Ç–∏—è —ç—Ç–∏—Ö —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º ‚Äì https://www.armosec.io/blog/kubernetes-vulner...

Avoiding CVE shock through Relevancy and Prioritization | ARMO

ARMO has released a new Kubernetes vulnerability prioritization feature based on eBPF technology to help users focus on the most critical issues affecting their security posture. Relevancy and prioritization allows users to deprioritize vulnerabilities that belong to unused software packages and components, thus reducing waste of resources and making the remediation process more efficient. The feature is based on an open-source agent that scans the running environment, mapping out all the libraries and artifacts that are loaded into memory, and the information collected¬†is used to identify and pinpoint the most critical vulnerabilities.¬†

- New Kubernetes vulnerability prioritization feature released by ARMO
- Relevancy and prioritization feature allows users to deprioritize vulnerabilities that belong to¬†unused software packages and components
- Based on an open-source agent that scans the running environment and maps out all the artifacts and libraries that are loaded into memory
- Helps vulnerability assessment and remediation process become more efficient and effective
- Reduces waste of resources, enabling¬†users to focus on addressing the most critical vulnerabilities
- The feature uses eBPF technology to identify and pinpoint the most critical vulnerabilities for each customer-specific environment
- The new feature has been added to Kubescape, the CNCF-hosted engine for scanning containers and clusters for misconfigurations and vulnerabilities.
